history.content: Took the classes in the opposite order. IMO, it might help a _little_, but I felt like 16A/B taught circuits adequately (at least when I took it).

children.subject: Nope 16 series makes note that there is no physics prerequisite

If you're an EECS major, then I would recommend taking Physics 7B when most people take it, which is during your sophomore year after having taken EE 16A/B your freshman year. It's not worth putting off EE 16A/B to get a little more preparation through Physics 7B.

If you're a CS major, I don't think you're required to take Physics 7B and it's definitely not a class that's worth taking just for exposure to more concepts.

If you still are unsure, this is my honest opinion about Physics 7B vs. EE 16A/B regarding circuits:

EE 16A and 16B approach circuits much more abstractly than Physics 7B. That is, in EE 16A/B circuits are taught as a set of mathematical rules that you can apply to diagrams. Physics 7B approaches circuits by first covering principles of electricity and then explaining everything in circuit diagrams from a physical perspective. If you take EE 16A/B before taking Physics 7B, and you've never been exposed to circuits before, you may find the abstract approach slightly confusing at first. However, if you take Physics 7B first, you will struggle more with actually solving circuit problems because you will have fewer mathematical tools to work with. If you had even a few weeks of circuits in a high school physics class, I think that's more than enough to feel comfortable with circuits as they're introduced in EE 16A. Even if you didn't, I think you should still probably be fine. The costs of putting off EE 16A/B to take Physics 7B first outweigh the benefits.

I am aware that there isn't a formal physics prerequisite for the 16 series, but I am wondering how beneficial/relevant physics 7b may be for EE 16A/B courses. Would you be better prepared for the 16 series having done physics 7b?

history.content: Is it helpful to take physics 7B before taking EE16A/B?
history.subject: EE 16A/B
